p.em: These exercises address the six trigonometric functions of an angle \theta in standard position as determined by the coordinates of a point on its terminal ray. \sin(\theta) = \frac{y}{r}, \quad \cos(\theta) = \frac{x}{r}, \quad \tan(\theta) = \frac{y}{x} and their reciprocals \csc(\theta) = \frac{r}{y} = \frac{1}{\sin(\theta)}, \quad \sec(\theta) = \frac{r}{x} = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}, \quad \cot(\theta) = \frac{x}{y} = \frac{1}{\tan(\theta)}.
The video reviews the trigonometric functions.

statement.p: Find all six trigonometric function values of the angle \theta in standard position whose terminal ray passes through the point (x,y) = (4,-1). See figure below.
Using a calculator, approximate the coordinates (x,y) of the point on the circle indicated in the figure below.

exercise.hint: The radius of the circle appears to be r = 4.

solution.p: The radius of the circle appears to be r = 4. Using a calculator, x = 4\times\cos (121^\circ) \approx -2.06015 and y = 4\times\sin (121^\circ) \approx 3.42867. Observe the signs of each are consistent with an angle in Quadrant II.

statement.p: Suppose \theta is an angle in standard position whose terminal ray is in Quadrant III satisfying \tan (\theta) = 3. Find the sine and cosine of \theta.
Suppose \theta is an angle in standard position whose terminal ray is in Quadrant III satisfying \sin (\theta) = -1/3. Find the cosine and tangent of \theta.
Suppose the terminal ray of an angle \theta in standard position is in Quadrant IV. Which of the six trigonometric function values of \theta are positive?

solution.p:
In Quadrant IV, x \gt 0 is positive and y \lt 0 is negative. Thus,
Sine is negative; and so is its reciprocal cosecant.
Cosine is positive; and so is its reciprocal secant.
Tangent is negative; and so is its reciprocal cotangent.
